item.title: Stock Futures Gain as Nvidia Posts Strong Results: Markets Wrap
item.description: US and Asian equity futures climbed after upbeat earnings from Nvidia Corp. boosted investor sentiment. Treasuries fell and the dollar strengthened.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

item.title: Chevron Gives Notice of Nearly 800 Job Cuts in Permian Basin
item.description: Chevron Corp. plans to lay off nearly 800 employees in the Permian Basin, where it operates its biggest US production operation.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Crowley

media:content.media:description: A Nabors Industries Ltd. roughneck uses a power washer to clean the drilling floor of a rig drilling for Chevron Corp. in the Permian Basin near Midland, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, March 1, 2018. Chevron, the world's third-largest publicly traded oil producer, is spending $3.3 billion this year in the Permian and an additional $1 billion in other shale basins. Its expansion will further bolster U.S. oil output, which already exceeds 10 million barrels a day, surpassing the record set in 1970.

item.title: FountainVest Seeks $1.32 Billion in Arc’teryx Maker Share Sale
item.description: An Asian private equity firm is seeking to raise as much as $1.32 billion in a sale of about half its shares in Amer Sports Inc., as early investors in the maker of sporting goods including Arc’teryx clothing look to cash out.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: An Arc'teryx store in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 4, 2024. Amer Sports Inc., the company behind sporting goods brands Wilson, Salomon and Arc'teryx, has filed for a US initial public offering.

item.title: The Commanders DC Deal with Josh Harris
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit down with 26North founder and Washington Commanders owner Josh Harris to hear about the team’s recent stadium deal in DC and his mindset on team ownership. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Argentina Sells Peso Bonds Abroad for First Time Since Macri Era
item.description: Argentina sold local currency debt to foreign investors, raising roughly $1 billion that will help boost central bank reserves a month after President Javier Milei’s government lifted most currency controls.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi, Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Argentina in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, April 14, 2025. Argentina reached a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund after President Javier Milei made sweeping changes to ease the nation's currency controls in a landmark moment for his government.

item.title: AI Adoption in 'Early Innings,' AI Fund's Andrew Ng Says
item.description: AI Fund Managing General Partner Andrew Ng says the value of artificial intelligence is steadily rising on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tropical Depression in Pacific Is Heading Toward Baja, California
item.description: A tropical depression has formed off Mexico’s Pacific Coast and will likely become Tropical Storm Alvin later Thursday as it churns north toward Baja California, the US National Hurricane Center said.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A tropical depression forming off Mexico’s Pacific Coast on May 28, 2025.

item.title: Nvidia’s Huang Can Navigate US-China Risks: Cleo’s Kunst
item.description: Cleo Capital Managing Director Sarah Kunst says Nvidia’s Jensen Huang is the “best-suited CEO” to deal with the recent US-China trade tensions on “Bloomberg The Close.” Nvidia said sales will be about $45 billion in the second fiscal quarter. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls.

item.title: Stocks Climb Late as Nvidia Reignites AI Hopes: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks climbed in late hours on speculation that Nvidia Corp.’s upbeat earnings will add fuel to the artificial intelligence-driven rally.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: Nvidia Posts Solid Sales Outlook Despite China Hit
item.description: Nvidia Corp., the world’s most valuable chipmaker, gave a solid revenue forecast for the current period, even as a slowdown in China weighed on results. Sales will be about $45 billion in the fiscal second quarter, which runs through July, the company said on Wednesday. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Victoria’s Secret Security Incident Disrupts Website, Email
item.description: Victoria’s Secret & Co. has stopped some office operations and told employees to avoid using company technology amid a “security incident” that also disrupted the retailer’s online shopping website and some store services.
item.dc:creator: Lara Sanli, Jeff Stone, Lily Meier

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk past a Victoria's Secret Stores LLC store in the Xidan shopping area in Beijing, China, on Wednesday, July 15, 2020. The Chinese economy returned to growth in the second quarter, marking an important milestone in the global struggle to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: The Key Takeaways From Nvidia’s Earnings
item.description: Wedbush Securities Equity Research Managing Director Matt Bryson breaks down Nvidia’s earnings and forecast on “Bloomberg The Close.” Nvidia said sales will be about $45 billion in the second fiscal quarter. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls.

item.title: State Street Files for Second Private ETF
item.description: State Street Corp. is set to double down on its bid to bring private assets to a broader spectrum of investors, even as its initial ETF experiment in this area has struggled to gain momentum. Bloomberg's Emily Graffeo reports (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Brazilian Airline Azul Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection in US
item.description: Azul SA filed for bankruptcy, the latest major Brazilian airline to seek protection from creditors after struggling for more than a year with higher expenses and the lingering impact of the pandemic on the aviation sector.
item.dc:creator: Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Rachel Gamarski

media:content.media:description: Passengers board an Azul Airlines passenger jet at Carajas Airport, in Parauapebas, Brazil. Photographer: Dado Galdieri/Bloomberg

item.title: Equities Retreat, Nvidia Earnings Loom | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bond Traders See Treasuries Selloff Going Even Further
item.description: Traders rattled by the rout in long-dated Treasuries are turning more bearish as yields continue to oscillate around a key 5% psychological threshold.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury department building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Macy's Maintains Sales Outlook
item.description: Macy’s Inc. posted better-than-expected quarterly results — a sign the company’s strategy of focusing on its best-performing locations is paying off despite weakening consumer sentiment and tariff volatility. Bloomberg's Romaine Bostick has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investors Snap Up Five-Year Treasuries in Show of Solid Demand
item.description: Solid investor demand at the Treasury Department’s $70 billion auction of new five-year notes offered the latest evidence of appetite for shorter-term securities.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Alice Gledhill

item.title: Jeffrey Katzenberg Says AI Is Not the End of Hollywood
item.description: Jeffrey Katzenberg, founding partner of WndrCo and co-founder of DreamWorks SKG, and Yinan Na, co-founder and CEO of Creatify, discuss launching Creatify, the first end-to-end AI ad agent specifically for video advertising, and the future of AI in the entertainment industry. They speak on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Buyout Firm Vista Nears $2 Billion Deal for Software Maker Acumatica
item.description: Vista Equity Partners is in advanced talks to acquire Acumatica Inc., a software company that helps businesses streamline workflow, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould, Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: High angle view of a businessman using laptop in a restaurant Photographer: FG Trade/E+

item.title: Bloomberg Markets 5/28/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Brave Eagle Wealth Management CEO Robert Ruggirello, Goldman Sachs Senior Analyst of Global Investment Research Bonnie Herzog, and Bloomberg's Romaine Bostick. . (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Improving National Security Through Cybersecurity
item.description: Wendi Whitmore, chief security intelligence officer at Palo Alto Networks, discusses what the US can do to improve its cyber defense and preparedness. Whitmore speaks ahead of her testimony to a House Committee on Homeland Security, with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Stocks Fall as Nvidia’s First-Quarter Earnings Draw Near
item.description: US stocks were lower on Wednesday as investors geared up for highly anticipated earnings from Nvidia Corp.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Defiance ETFs CEO on the Popularity of Levered ETFs
item.description: Recent stock volatility can't keep investors away from one of the market’s riskiest corners: levered ETFs. Defiance ETFs CEO and CIO Sylvia Jablonski discusses the popularity of the funds and the particular performance of the Defiance Daily Target 2X Long IONQ ETF (ticker: IONX) on "Bloomberg ETF IQ." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Navitas Rides Nvidia Coattails With Energy Partnership
item.description: Navitas Semiconductor shares have soared after the maker of power-efficient chips announced a partnership with Nvidia. CEO Gene Sheridan discusses the company’s supply chain and how its chips could fit into Nvidia’s international plans. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Greenlight Capital’s Einhorn Is Net Long Europe, Neutral on US
item.description: Greenlight Capital Inc. founder David Einhorn is long Europe, particularly the region’s industrials, after seeing tailwinds from government stimulus efforts, falling global energy prices and the prospect of a peace deal in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: David Einhorn, portfolio manager and co-founder of Greenlight Capital LLC, during an interview for an episode of Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein in New York, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Einhorn called tariffs “a regressive tax” that will force the US Federal Reserve to act, as President Donald Trump’s higher-than-expected global tariffs shocked investors and sent markets tumbling.

item.title: Why YouTube Increasingly Has Longer Shows
item.description: Bloomberg’s Lucas Shaw explains why YouTube creators are making longer content and what that means for attracting advertisers. Shaw joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Freepoint Commodities Ex-Analyst Claims Illegal Retaliation
item.description: A former senior analyst with Freepoint Commodities LLC claims he was fired from the energy-trading firm for resisting pressure to cooperate with executives in illegal insider trading, market manipulation and trade-theft schemes.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: The Thurgood Marshall federal courthouse in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Dec. 22, 2021. The Maxwell jury began deliberations on Monday after hearing closing arguments in the trial. The British socialite is charged with luring and grooming underage girls for abuse by her ex-boyfriend, Jeffrey Epstein. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Downplays Musk Tax Bill Criticism, Says Need to Win Votes
item.description: President Donald Trump dismissed criticism from Elon Musk, his billionaire donor and adviser, over the cost of his signature tax bill, telling reporters on Wednesday that compromises were made to secure the necessary votes. “Number one, we have to get a lot of votes,” Trump said. “We can’t be cutting — you know, we need, we need to get a lot of support.” Musk, who led the Department of Government Efficiency as part of a bid to cut federal spending, told CBS News in an interview that he was “disappointed to see the massive spending bill, frankly, which increases the budget deficit, not just decreases it, and undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing.” Musk’s comments echo some fiscal hawks who have argued that Trump’s “big, beautiful bill” — which pairs new tax cuts with an increase to military and border spending — could add trillions to the deficit. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Atlanta Mayor Says City 'Ready' For 2026 World Cup Games
item.description: The White House will ask Congress next week to enact $9 billion of spending cuts into law — a small portion of the $175 billion in savings that Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency claims to have found. The cuts — first floated in April but waylaid amid efforts in the House to pass President Donald Trump’s tax bill — would target funding for the Public Broadcasting Service, National Public Radio and foreign aid in the current fiscal year, according to an Office of Management and Budget spokeswoman. These cuts have also hit the CDC, and impacted the city of Atlanta, where many CDC employees live. Mayor Andre Dickens discussed how Atlanta's budget is hurt from the job losses, and also discussed the city's readiness for the 2026 FIFA World Cup. (Source: Bloomberg)
